article.title: Tool Accessibility
article.subtitle: Defining a standard way to test tools for accessibility

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: While there has been an emphasis in web accessibility for websites and the retrofitting of existing web content there hasn't been a consistent effort to test content creation tools for their creation of accessible content and how accessible the tools themselves are.

This project seeks to address these issues by providing both a methodology and a selection of tools to test. It also seeks to create awareness regarding testing methodologies and how they can be applied to evaluating technology.

sect1.title: Problem Statement
sect1.para: Each California State University campus uses it own set of tools to develop content for their online delivery. In the past it was ok to use an HTML editor such as Adobe DreamWeaver to create content. Now faculty want immediate results and don't care as much about the underlying technology that allows to create content but want the content to be created with minimal effort and maximum results.
Students expectations have also evolved over the years. Where it was OK to just convert a Word Document to HTML now students want better quality on their instructional materials.

This project seeks to provide an initial knowledge base regarding content creation tools accessibility and as a springboard for Universities to select their tools knowing that they produce accessible content

sect1.title: Methodology
sect1.para: To avoid upsetting the balance in individual campuses the team will conduct a survey to determine which, if any, authoring tools are being used by each. This will provide an initial list of tools to evaluate.
